revision.text: {{Article history |action1=GAN |action1date=14:13, 19 October 2014 (UTC) |action1link=/GA1 |action1result=failed |action1oldid=629767936 |action2=GAN |action2date=02:32, 7 November 2014 (UTC) |action2link=/GA2 |action2result=passed |action2oldid=632778282 |currentstatus=GA |topic=media and drama }} {{WikiProjectBannerShell|1= {{WikiProject Film|American-task-force=yes|class=GA|Italian-task-force=yes|French-task-force=yes}} {{WikiProject Horror|class=GA|importance=low}} {{WikiProject Italy|class=GA|importance=low}} }} ==OPLY?== Do you really think, that Aleksey Konstantinovich Tolstoy (August 24 1817 – October 10 1875)wrote the screenplay? — Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/91.66.189.125|91.66.189.125]] ([[User talk:91.66.189.125|talk]]) 11:04, 6 September 2012 (UTC) :No, the stories are claimed to be based of their works, but they never created such stories apparently. [[User:Andrzejbanas|Andrzejbanas]] ([[User talk:Andrzejbanas|talk]]) 07:51, 29 March 2014 (UTC) ==Excessively Detailed?== I looked for this article because the film is airing right now, and I was curious about it. I think the plot summaries are just right; I appreciated the amount of detail without thinking it was long-winded, and I wouldn't insist on cutting them. [[Special:Contributions/71.79.244.206|71.79.244.206]] ([[User talk:71.79.244.206|talk]]) 07:13, 22 July 2011 (UTC) :I trimmed it a bit just to have it within our guidelines. There was only a few things that needed re-arranging. [[User:Andrzejbanas|Andrzejbanas]] ([[User talk:Andrzejbanas|talk]]) 07:51, 29 March 2014 (UTC) == Rem demonstrably false statement == I just performed a needed trim on the article, and in the process removed a statement that is demonstrably false. The statement seemed to claim that Snyder and Tolstoy are fictional characters. [[Aleksey Konstantinovich Tolstoy]] is obviously ''not'' a fictional character, and the same paragraph two sentences later provided [[The Family of the Vourdalak|the title of his novella]] that was used as the source for the segment, "The Wurdulak" (and it appears to my shaky knowledge of Russian to be a fair translation of the title given in the film credits). I therefore have no idea what the offending sentence was meant to say; Tolstoy is not fictional, the title given as the source for the film segment really exists and has a similar plot and identically-named characters. I can't vouch for F. G. Snyder, however; all references to him point back to this film. If someone wants to restore the claim that F. G. Snyder is fictional, find a source to back your claim. [[Special:Contributions/12.233.147.42|12.233.147.42]] ([[User talk:12.233.147.42|talk]]) 02:51, 8 January 2015 (UTC)
